bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, September 12, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant William Dawkins, September 12, 1728, to order silver spoons, wooden-handled knives and forks, and pistol powder and shot.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, September 12, 1728

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr. the 12th. 1728
Mr. Wm. Dawkins

div1.p:
I hope this will have the luck to get to you time
Enough I desire you to Send me in a doz: Strong Substantial Silver
Spoons to have the two first Letters of my name upon them I also
desire you to Send me in four hundred weight of Drop Shott, & a
Barrell of the best Pistole powder One half of the Shot to be that
Sort thats calld Bristol Shot the other half a Smaller Size, also
to Send me a Case of a doz:Strong wooden handled fashionable
knives and forks, which Shall be all at Present from
div1.closer:
Sir
Yor humble Servt.
per Raymond Copy per Nayler

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] Carter sent letters by Captain Naylor in the fall of 1728, but apparently the ship was lost on its way to Liverpool because Carter noted to William Dawkins 1728 June 29, the ship "hath never been heard of."
